There are two methoxy groups, so 2 * +20°C = +40°C. - The acetic acid side chain (–CH2–COOH) contains both a methylene group and a carboxylic acid functional group. The methylene group (+CH2) has a smaller effect and can slightly raise the melting point, estimated at +5°C. The carboxylic acid group is capable of strong hydrogen bonding, significantly raising the melting point; this effect can be estimated at around +50°C. Combining these, the acetic acid side chain contributes approximately +55°C in the increase of the melting point. - The cumulative effect of the two methoxy groups and the acetic acid side chain would thus be approximately +40°C (methoxy) + +55°C (acetic) from the base benzene structure. Therefore, the predicted melting point would be 5.5°C (benzene) + 95°C (functional group contributions) = 100.5°C.
Test (Predicted reason):
The target compound, (3,4-Dimethoxyphenyl)acetic acid, has several functional groups that influence its melting point: a phenyl ring, two methoxy groups, and an acetic acid group. Starting with benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C, the introduction of each functional group can increase the melting point due to added molecular weight and potential for intermolecular interactions. The phenyl ring contributes to an increase in the melting point due to π-π interactions and increased molecular rigidity; this can be estimated at about +25°C. The acetic acid group is capable of forming strong hydrogen bonds, which significantly raises the melting point; this can be estimated at about +40°C.
